Situation1: Celebrate each other's achievements and milestones.
Expectation2: Conduct experiments to test hypotheses and gather data
Situation2: The experiment is reserved during a limited window when specialized instruments are available.
Story: I stared at my phone, my sister’s excited message lighting up the screen: “Don’t forget, tonight’s the big dinner! I can’t wait to celebrate with you!” She’d just landed her dream job, and our family was gathering to toast her success. I knew how much it meant to her—she’d always been there for me, cheering me on, and I wanted to do the same. But as I glanced at the lab schedule, my heart sank. The specialized microscope I needed for my experiment was only available tonight, after weeks of waiting. If I missed this window, I’d have to delay my research, maybe even lose the chance to publish first. My advisor was counting on me, and so was my team. I felt torn in two, the weight of my sister’s expectations pressing on one side, the demands of my scientific work on the other. My hands trembled as I tried to figure out how to be both the supportive sister and the dedicated scientist, knowing I couldn’t fully be both at once.
